answers.author: Pooja Varma
answers.text:
Hi Lisa,
I found some policies on naming trails and parks that should be useful for you.
Alaska’s Department of Natural Resources Policy document that requires trail names to be “descriptive of origin- destination, or the character of the country through which the trail passes.”
http://dnr.alaska.gov/parks/plans/chugach/trailpln/csptrail_ch3.pdf 
Denver Parks and Recreation Policy and Procedures that involves the City Council and DPR Advisory board, DPR Manager and also provides their general principles for choosing names such as social significance, positive image, symbolic value and so on. 
http://denvergov.org/Portals/626/documents/Naming%20P&R%20Facilities%20Policy%20signed.pdf 
Portland, Oregon’s Parks and Recreation Policy that includes the general procedures for naming/ renaming parks as well as the process for requests for naming. 
http://www.portlandonline.com/parks/index.cfm?a=217384&c=43957 
City of Niagara Falls, Canada’s Naming and Renaming of Parks Policy that provides the criteria that names should meet. 
http://www.niagarafalls.ca/city_hall/departments/parks_recreation_and_culture/parks/pdf/rename_parks_policy.pdf 
I hope this is helpful,
Pooja Varma
International City/County Management Association
Knowledge Network Intern
pvarma@icma.org

author: Lisa Granahan
text: I'm looking for trail naming processes, policies or procedures used by other counties.  Douglas County, Nevada has a non-profit group that does much of our trail development.  For the most part trails have gotten geographical, historical, or private parties names if easements are granted.  This has worked well.  We are getting ready to involve the community in a process to name a significant loop trail around the entire valley.  I'm interested in the ways other jurisdictions arrive at names for segment and substantial trails.
title: Trail naming processes and procedures
